review: In all fairness, this is a nice product.  It works well.  It's small and compact enough to move around easily.  And I can control the playback and TV volume of what I'm watching, from my smartphone, computer, or tablet.  But I'm biased.  I've got the Google Chromecast on my TV in the kitchen and the Amazon Fire TV on the TV in the bedroom.  Given the choice: I'd much rather use the Amazon Fire TV device leaving my smartphone available for other things.However, one advantage of Chromecast is that it can be used to stream any source that you can playback on your laptop, tablet, or smartphone directly to whatever TV it's plugged into.  For business use, this means that visitors can stream their Powerpoint presentations or marketing videos directly to the TV in the conference room -- no need to hook up an HDMI cable and string it across the room.
author: P. Swarthout "Computer Junkie"

review: I bought this specifically so I could broadcast CBS.com to my TV.  The CBS app for my Roku requires a subscription for recent content that is free on the computer and tablet, so I thought I would give this a try, since it will pay for itself in 6 months.  I'm impressed.  It's easy to set up and use, and there is something to be said for controlling the content from a tablet or phone.  Plus, it's just hard to beat the price.  The one thing it will not do is Amazon Instant Video from my iPad, which was not a surprise, since Amazon is a competitor.
